{{Infobox protected area | name = Spirit Mound Historic Prairie | iucn_category = | iucn_ref = <!-- images --> | photo = Spirit Mound Historic Prairie 1a.jpg | photo_caption = Spirit Mound <!-- map --> | map = USA South Dakota | map_image = | map_size = | map_caption = Location of Spirit Mound Historic Prairie in South Dakota | relief = 1 <!-- location --> | location = [[Clay County, South Dakota|Clay]], [[South Dakota]], [[United States]] | nearest_city = | nearest_town = | coordinates = {{coord|42|52|28|N|96|57|33|W|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = <!-- stats --> | length = | length_mi = | length_km = | width = | width_mi = | width_km = | area_acre = 320 | area_ref = | elevation = {{convert|1280|ft|m|abbr=on}}<ref>{{cite web | url={{Gnis3|1265382}} | title=Spirit Mound | date = 1980-02-13 | work=[[Geographic Names Information System]] | publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]] | accessdate=2011-02-28}}</ref> | elevation_avg = | elevation_min = | elevation_max = | dimensions = | designation = <!-- dates & info --> | authorized = | created = | designated = | established = 2001 | named_for = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_ref = | governing_body = South Dakota Game, Fish & Parks | administrator = | operator = | owner = <!-- website, embedded --> | website = | embedded = }}
'''Spirit Mound Historic Prairie''' is a [[state park]] of [[South Dakota]], USA, featuring a prominent hill on the [[Great Plains]]. The [[Plains Indians]] of the region considered Spirit Mound the home of dangerous spirits or [[little people (mythology)|little people]]; members of the [[Lewis and Clark Expedition]] climbed it on August 25, 1804. The park was established in 2002.<ref>Sapp, Methea; Enright, Kelly; Nichols, Terri; Ney, Jason; and Dreese, Donelle N. ''America's Natural Places.'' Santa Barbara, Calif.: Greenwood/ABC-CLIO, 2010, p. 102.</ref> It is located about {{convert|6.5|mi|km}} north of [[Vermillion, South Dakota]].<ref>McMacken, Robin. ''The Dakotas: Off the Beaten Path.'' Guilford, Conn.: Globe Pequot Press, 2008, p. 44.</ref>
==About Spirit Mound== Stories and religious beliefs about "Little People" are common to many if not most Native American tribes in the West.<ref name="Saindon478">[https://books.google.com/books?id=TygK-g-UguQC&lpg=PA481&dq=%22Pryor%20Mountains%22%20dwarves&pg=PA480#v=onepage&q&f=false Saindon, Robert A. "Lewis and Clark and the Legend of the 'Little People'." In ''Explorations Into the World of Lewis and Clark.'' Robert A. Saindon, ed. Great Falls, Mont.: Lewis and Clark Trail Heritage Foundation, 2003, p. 478.]</ref><ref name="PlentyCoups23">[https://books.google.com/books?id=B6oMQY0pS2oC&lpg=PA23&dq=%22Plenty%20Coups%22%20little%20person&pg=PA19#v=onepage&q=%22Plenty%20Coups%22%20little%20person&f=false Plenty Coups and Linderman, Frank Bird. ''Plenty-Coups, Chief of the Crows.'' Lincoln, Neb.: University of Nebraska Press, 2002, p. 23.]</ref><ref name="Lawrence17">[https://books.google.com/books?id=UyFKtTTr-D4C&lpg=PA19&dq=%22Pryor%20Mountains%22%20%22Medicine%20Rock%22&pg=PA15#v=onepage&q=Little%20People&f=false Lawrence, Edward. ''Mysteries and Legends of Montana: True Stories of the Unsolved and Unexplained.'' Helena, Mont.: Twodot, 1997, p. 17.]</ref> In 1804, the [[Lewis and Clark Expedition]] stayed for a time with a band of [[Sioux|Wičhíyena Sioux]] on the [[Vermillion River (South Dakota)|Vermillion River]] in modern-day South Dakota. On August 25, [[Meriwether Lewis]], [[William Clark (explorer)|William Clark]], and 10 other men traveled about {{convert|9|mi}} north of the river's junction with the [[Missouri River]] to see the "mountain of the Little People".<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=TygK-g-UguQC&lpg=PA481&dq=%22Pryor%20Mountains%22%20dwarves&pg=PA480#v=onepage&q&f=false Saindon, "Lewis and Clark and the Legend of the 'Little People'," in ''Explorations Into the World of Lewis and Clark,'' 2003, p. 479-480.]</ref> Lewis wrote in his journal that the Little People were "deavals" (devils) with very large heads, about {{convert|18|in|cm}} high, and very alert to any intrusions into their territory.<ref name="Lewis">[https://books.google.com/books?id=h8Wfa-KwjX4C&lpg=PA544&dq=journal%20of%20lewis%20and%20clark&pg=PA505#v=onepage&q=%22little%20People%22&f=false Lewis, Meriwether and Clark, William. ''The Journals of the Lewis & Clark Expedition, Vol. 3: August 25, 1804 – April 6, 1805.'' Gary E. Moulton, ed. Lincoln, Neb.: University of Nebraska Press, 1987, p. 505.]</ref> The Sioux said that the devils carried sharp arrows which could strike at a very long distance, and that they killed anyone who approached their mound.<ref name="Lewis" /><ref name="Lawrence18">[https://books.google.com/books?id=UyFKtTTr-D4C&lpg=PA19&dq=%22Pryor%20Mountains%22%20%22Medicine%20Rock%22&pg=PA18#v=onepage&q=Little%20People&f=false Lawrence, ''Mysteries and Legends of Montana: True Stories of the Unsolved and Unexplained,'' 1997, p. 18.]</ref> The Little People so terrified the local population, Lewis reported, that the Maha ([[Omaha (tribe)|Omaha]]), Ottoes ([[Otoe tribe|Otoe]]), and Sioux would not go near the place.<ref name="Lewis" /> The [[Lakota people]] who came to live near the "Spirit Mound" after the Wičhíyena Sioux have a story no more than 250 years old which describes how a band of 350 warriors came near the mound late at night and were nearly wiped out by the ferocious Little People (the survivors were crippled for life).<ref name="Saindon481">[https://books.google.com/books?id=TygK-g-UguQC&lpg=PA481&dq=%22Pryor%20Mountains%22%20dwarves&pg=PA480#v=onepage&q&f=false Saindon, "Lewis and Clark and the Legend of the 'Little People'," in ''Explorations Into the World of Lewis and Clark,'' 2003, p. 481.]</ref>
Due to extensive damming of the [[Missouri River]], Spirit Mound is one of the few places which historians can identify as a precise spot upon which Lewis and Clark stood .<ref>Fanselow, Julie. ''Traveling the Lewis and Clark Trail.'' Guilford, Conn.: Falcon Guides, 2007, p. 72.</ref>
==About the park== Spirit Mound was in private hands for many decades, leading to extensive degradation of the site's original status.<ref>[http://siouxcityjournal.com/news/local/a1/article_e667ac40-d944-5df8-8f28-1d046a78bca6.html Sioux City Journal], "''Is Spirit Mound shrinking?''," by Michele Linck (November 7th, 2010 - retrieved on November 6th, 2013).</ref> White settlers first came to the area in 1868, and used it for grazing livestock and for farming.<ref name="News2005">[http://www.spiritmound.com/Newsletters/2003.pdf Wilson, Norma C. "Grass Dance Special for Spirit Mound." ''Spirit Mound Trust News.'' 2005.]</ref> Five separate landowners owned parts of the site in the early 1980s.<ref name="News2003">[http://www.spiritmound.com/Newsletters/2003.pdf "In the Footsteps of Lewis and Clark." ''Lewis and Clark - Spirit Mound Trust News.'' 2003.]</ref> More than 20 buildings, a feed lot, soybean fields, corn fields, several roads, 1,500 non-native trees, and {{convert|5|mi|km}} of fence dotted the site.<ref name="News2003" />
Several local citizens formed the Spirit Mound Trust in 1986 in an attempt to preserve the site.<ref name="News2003" /><ref>Harriman, Peter. "Federal Money Boosts Spirit Mound." ''Sioux Falls Argus Leader.'' April 22, 2001.</ref> The group received funding boosts and publicity with the 1996 publication of the book ''[[Undaunted Courage]]'' (about the Lewis and Clark Expedition) and the 1997 [[Ken Burns]] documentary ''[[Lewis & Clark: The Journey of the Corps of Discovery]]''.<ref name="History">[http://www.spiritmound.com/historyofthetrust.htm "Spirit Mound Trust History." No date.] Accessed 2010-09-02.</ref> After years of lobbying, the federal government's [[Land and Water Conservation Fund]] provided $600,000 to acquire the site.<ref>"Lewis and Clark Exploration Site Gets Federal Money for Restoration." ''[[Associated Press]].'' October 21, 1998.</ref> The donation required that State of South Dakota establish the site as a state park, while the Spirit Mound Trust would restore it, provide interpretational signage and tours, and raise $500,000 for the site's long-term preservation.<ref name="History" /> The {{convert|320|acre|ha|adj=on}} site was purchased from the private landowners in 2001.<ref>"Spirit Mound Land Has Been Purchased." ''Associated Press.'' April 21, 2001.</ref> On July 29, 2001, [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Tim Johnson (U.S. Senator)|Tim Johnson]] presented a symbolic check for $600,000 for the purchase of Spirit Mound and the surrounding land.<ref>Morast, Robert. "Ceremony Marks Purchase by State." ''Sioux Falls Argus Leader.'' July 30, 2001.</ref>
In 2004 the [[United States Department of the Interior]] designated the trail leading to the summit of Spirit Mound as a [[National Recreation Trail]].<ref name="News2004">[http://www.spiritmound.com/Newsletters/2003.pdf Heisinger, Jim. "National Designation for Spirit Mound Summit Trail." ''Spirit Mound Trust News.'' 2004.]</ref>
The [[Spirit Mound Creek]] runs right past the Mound, on its southern side.<ref>''Aliens in American History: Book I - Spirit Mound'', by John Clark Craig and E.J. Thornton, Phenomenon Publishing, 2011 (page 50).</ref>
Some controversy has surrounded the establishment of the state park. In 2001 a few local Native American leaders expressed dismay that a site sacred and terrifying to local tribes would be treated as a "fun" place to visit.<ref>"Some American Indians Not Pleased With Plans for Spiritual Site." ''Associated Press.'' April 6, 2001.</ref>

{{Taxobox | regnum = [[Bacteria]] | phylum = [[Firmicutes]] | classis = ''[[Incertae sedis]]'' | genus = ''Sulfobacillus'' | genus_authority = Golovacheva and Karavaiko 1991<ref name=lpsn /> | type_species = ''[[Sulfobacillus thermosulfidooxidans]]''<ref name=lpsn /> | subdivision_ranks = [[Species]] | subdivision = {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * ''[[Sulfobacillus acidophilus]]'' * ''[[Sulfobacillus benefaciens]]'' * ''[[Sulfobacillus disulfidooxidans]]'' * ''[[Sulfobacillus sibiricus]]'' * ''[[Sulfobacillus thermosulfidooxidans]]'' ([[type species]]) }} | synonyms = }}
'''''Sulfobacillus''''' is a [[genus (biology)|genus]] of [[bacteria]] containing five named [[species (biology)|species]]. Members of the genus are [[Gram-positive]], [[acidophilic]], [[sporulation|spore-forming]] bacteria that are moderately [[thermophilic]] or thermotolerant. All species are [[facultative anaerobes]] capable of [[oxidizing]] [[sulfur]]-containing compounds; they differ in optimal growth temperature and metabolic capacity, particularly in their ability to grow on various [[organic compound|organic carbon compounds]].<ref name="justice_2014">{{cite journal |last1=Justice |first1=Nicholas B |last2=Norman |first2=Anders |last3=Brown |first3=Christopher T |last4=Singh |first4=Andrea |last5=Thomas |first5=Brian C |last6=Banfield |first6=Jillian F |title=Comparison of environmental and isolate Sulfobacillus genomes reveals diverse carbon, sulfur, nitrogen, and hydrogen metabolisms |journal=BMC Genomics |date=2014 |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=1107 |doi=10.1186/1471-2164-15-1107}}</ref><ref name="guo_2014">{{cite journal |last1=Guo |first1=Xue |last2=Yin |first2=Huaqun |last3=Liang |first3=Yili |last4=Hu |first4=Qi |last5=Zhou |first5=Xishu |last6=Xiao |first6=Yunhua |last7=Ma |first7=Liyuan |last8=Zhang |first8=Xian |last9=Qiu |first9=Guanzhou |last10=Liu |first10=Xueduan |last11=Mormile |first11=Melanie R. |title=Comparative Genome Analysis Reveals Metabolic Versatility and Environmental Adaptations of Sulfobacillus thermosulfidooxidans Strain ST |journal=PLoS ONE |date=18 June 2014 |volume=9 |issue=6 |pages=e99417 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0099417}}</ref><ref name="zhang_2017">{{cite journal |last1=Zhang |first1=Xian |last2=Liu |first2=Xueduan |last3=Liang |first3=Yili |last4=Guo |first4=Xue |last5=Xiao |first5=Yunhua |last6=Ma |first6=Liyuan |last7=Miao |first7=Bo |last8=Liu |first8=Hongwei |last9=Peng |first9=Deliang |last10=Huang |first10=Wenkun |last11=Zhang |first11=Yuguang |last12=Yin |first12=Huaqun |last13=Drake |first13=Harold L. |title=Adaptive Evolution of Extreme Acidophile Sulfobacillus thermosulfidooxidans Potentially Driven by Horizontal Gene Transfer and Gene Loss |journal=Applied and Environmental Microbiology |date=1 April 2017 |volume=83 |issue=7 |doi=10.1128/AEM.03098-16}}</ref><ref name="dopson_2016">{{cite book |last1=Dopson |first1=Mark |editor1-last=Quatrini |editor1-first=Raquel |title=Acidophiles : life in extremely acidic environments |date=2016 |publisher=Caister Academic Press |isbn=1910190349 |pages=79-91 |chapter=Physiological and Phylogenetic Diversity of Acidophilic Bacteria}}</ref>
==Taxonomy== ''Sulfobacillus'' was first described in 1978, along with the [[type species]], ''[[Sulfobacillus thermosulfidooxidans]]''.<ref name="golovacheva_1978">{{cite journal |last1=Golovacheva |first1=RS |last2=Karavaĭko |first2=GI |title=[Sulfobacillus, a new genus of thermophilic sporulating bacteria]. |journal=Mikrobiologiia |date=1978 |volume=47 |issue=5 |pages=815-22 |pmid=101742}}</ref><ref name="lpsn">{{cite web |title=Genus Sulfobacillus |url=http://www.bacterio.net/sulfobacillus.html |website=List of Prokaryotic Names with Standing in Nomenclature |accessdate=18 November 2018}}</ref> Four additional species have since been described, in at least one case discovered after samples believed to be ''S. thermosulfidooxidans'' showed unexpected characteristics.<ref name="norris_1996">{{cite journal |last1=Norris |first1=P. R. |last2=Clark |first2=D. A. |last3=Owen |first3=J. P. |last4=Waterhouse |first4=S. |title=Characteristics of Sulfobacillus acidophilus sp. nov. and other moderately thermophilic mineral-sulphide-oxidizing bacteria |journal=Microbiology |date=1 April 1996 |volume=142 |issue=4 |pages=775–783 |doi=10.1099/00221287-142-4-775}}</ref>
The genus is of uncertain taxonomic position. It was originally placed in the [[Clostridiales]]. It is likely related to the genus ''[[Thermaerobacter]]'' and may represent either a deep branch of the ''[[Firmicutes]]'' or a separate [[phylum]].<ref name=guo_2014 /><ref name=lpsn /><ref name="bergeys">{{cite book |last1=Ludwig |first1=Wolfgang |last2=Schleifer |first2=Karl-Heinz |last3=Whitman |first3=William B. |editor1-last=Vos |editor1-first=Paul |editor2-last=Garrity |editor2-first=George |editor3-last=Jones |editor3-first=Dorothy |editor4-last=Krieg |editor4-first=Noel R. |editor5-last=Ludwig |editor5-first=Wolfgang |editor6-last=Rainey |editor6-first=Fred A. |editor7-last=Schleifer |editor7-first=Karl-Heinz |editor8-last=Whitman |editor8-first=William B. |title=Bergey's Manual of Systematic Bacteriology Volume 3: The Firmicutes |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-0-387-95041-9 |edition=2nd |chapter=Revised road map to the phylum Firmicutes}}</ref>
==Ecology== ''Sulfobacillus'' species are found globally in both natural and artificial [[acidic]] environments, such as [[hot spring]]s, [[solfatara]] environments, [[hydrothermal vent]]s, and in various forms of [[acid mine drainage]]. Compared to other bacterial species found in similar acidic environments, ''Sulfobacillus'' species are often present at relatively low abundance.<ref name=justice_2014 />
==Genome== The [[genome]]s of several ''Sulfobacillus'' species have been [[DNA sequencing|sequenced]].<ref name=justice_2014 /><ref name=guo_2014 /><ref name=zhang_2017 /> Differences between members include genome size and gene content related to sulfur oxidation pathways.<ref name=justice_2014 />
